div1.head: Military Orders for Theodore C. Lyster and Walter Reed, December 27, 1900 [selected pages]
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders
Vol 2 - 1900

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, December 27, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Abram C.
Douglas, Hospital Corps, now at Fort McDowell, California,
will be discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by the
commanding officer of that post. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Joseph B.
Jensen, Hospital Corps, Manila, Philippine Islands, is trans-
ferred to the 6th Cavalry, stationed at that place. He will
report to the commanding officer of that regiment for assign-
ment to a troop now serving in the Philippines.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Fred K.
Ross. Company M, 23d Infantry, now at Fort D. A. Russell,
Wyoming, is transferred to the Hospital Corps. Upon receipt
of this order at the post the commanding officer will order the
soldier to report to the surgeon for duty in the hospital.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Pablo Gim-
inez, Company D, Porto Rico Regiment, U. S. Volunteers, San
Juan, Porto Rico, will be discharged from the Army by the
commanding officer of his station, by reason of being unsuited
to the service. This soldier is entitled to travel-pay.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Michael
J. Costello, Company E, 15th Infantry, now in the hands of
the civil authorities serving sentence of imprisonment, will
be discharged without honor from the Army by the command-
ing officer. Plattsburg Barracks, New York. This soldier is
not entitled to travel-pay.

6. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Richard B.
Baxter, jr., Hospital Corps, Fort McPherson, Georgia, will be
discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by the command-
ing officer of that post on January 13, 1901. This soldier is
not entitled to travel-pay.

7. By direction of the Secretary of War, Musician Robert
Brown, Company L, 23d Infantry, now at Fort Douglas, Utah,
will be discharged from the Army by the commanding officer

20. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following
changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical
Department and acting assistant surgeons, U. S. Army, are
ordered:

First Lieutenant Major A. W. Schockley, assistant surgeon,
U. S. Army, is relieved from further duty in the Department
of Cuba, and will proceed to Fort Niobrara, Nebraska, and
report in person to the commanding officer of that post for
duty and by letter to the commanding general, Department of
the Missouri, to relieve Acting Assistant Surgeon Clark I.
Wertenbaker. Acting Assistant Surgeon Wertenbaker upon
being thus relieved will proceed to San Francisco, California,
and report in person to the commanding general, Department
of California, for assignment to duty with troops destined for
the Philippine Islands, where upon arrival he will report in
person to the commanding general, Division of the Philip-
pines, for assignment to duty.

First Lieutenant Theodore C. Lyster, assistant surgeon, U. S.
Army, is relieved from further duty in the Department of
Cuba, and will proceed to Fort Schuyler, New York, and re-
port in person to the commanding officer of that post for duty
and by letter to the commanding general, Department of the
East, to relieve Acting Assistant Surgeon William H. Brooks.
Acting Assistant Surgeon Brooks upon being thus relieved will
proceed to obey the requirements of paragraph 14, Special
Orders, No. 258, November 2, 1900, from this office.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

21. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, is detailed to represent the Med-
ical Department of the Army at the Pan-American Medical
Congress to meet in the city of Havana, Cuba, February 5,
1901, in addition to the officers designated in paragraph 9,
Special Orders, No. 266, November 12, 1900, from this office.

22. By direction of the Secretary of War, so much of para-
graph 12, Special Orders, No. 282, December 1, 1900, from this
office, as relates to Acting Assistant Surgeon J. Samuel White,
U. S. Army, is so amended as to direct him to report in person
to the commanding general, Department of California, for
assignment to duty at the General Hospital, Presidio of San
Francisco, California.
